questions.title: Sine Wave with Phase Shift
questions.question_text: For $v(t) = 2\sin(2\pi t + \pi/2)$, determine amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $A = 2$, $\omega = 2\pi$ gives $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, phase shift $\phi = \pi/2$ radians.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard form: $A \sin(\omega t + \phi)$. Extract $A = 2$, $\omega = 2\pi \to f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = \pi/2$.

questions.title: Negative Amplitude Cosine
questions.question_text: For $i(t) = -3\cos(6\pi t)$, what are the correct amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Amplitude $A$ is always positive: $A = 3$. $\omega = 6\pi$ gives $f = 3\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Amplitude $A = |\text{coefficient}| = 3$ (always positive). $\omega = 6\pi \to f = 6\pi/(2\pi) = 3\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Sine Wave Parameter Analysis
questions.question_text: For the sinusoidal function $v(t) = 0.5\sin(8\pi t)$, calculate the frequency $f$ in $\text{Hz}$ using $f = \omega/(2\pi)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\omega = 8\pi\,\text{rad/s}$, so $f = 8\pi/(2\pi) = 4\,\text{Hz}$. Amplitude $A = 0.5$, phase $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Extract angular frequency: $\omega = 8\pi$ from $8\pi t$, then apply $f = \omega/(2\pi) = 8\pi/(2\pi) = 4\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Complete Sine Wave Analysis
questions.question_text: For $v(t) = 0.5\sin(8\pi t)$, determine amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $A = 0.5$, $\omega = 8\pi$ gives $f = 4\,\text{Hz}$, no phase term means $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard form: $A \sin(\omega t + \phi)$. Here $A = 0.5$, $\omega = 8\pi \to f = 4\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = 0$.

questions.title: Frequency from Period Analysis
questions.question_text: A sine wave completes one full cycle in $T = 1.0\,\text{s}$. Calculate its frequency $f$ using $f = 1/T$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f = 1/T = 1/1.0\,\text{s} = 1.0\,\text{Hz}$. Frequency is the reciprocal of period.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the relationship $f = 1/T$ where $T$ is the period. $f = 1/1.0\,\text{s} = 1.0\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Phase Shift Identification
questions.question_text: For a standard sine wave $y(t) = \sin(\omega t)$ with no horizontal displacement, the phase shift $\phi = \_\_\_\_\_$ radians.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Standard sine function $\sin(\omega t)$ has $\phi = 0$ (no phase shift).
questions.feedback_incorrect: A standard sine wave with no horizontal shift has phase $\phi = 0$ radians.

questions.title: Cosine Amplitude Measurement
questions.question_text: A cosine wave oscillates between $+2\,\text{V}$ and $-2\,\text{V}$. Calculate its amplitude $A$ in volts.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Amplitude $A = (\text{max} - \text{min})/2 = (2\,\text{V} - (-2\,\text{V}))/2 = 2\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Amplitude is half the peak-to-peak value: $A = (V_{max} - V_{min})/2 = 4\,\text{V}/2 = 2\,\text{V}$.

questions.title: Phase-Shifted Cosine Analysis
questions.question_text: A cosine wave shows a phase shift of $\phi = \pi/4$ radians. This represents:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\phi = \pi/4\,\text{rad} = 45\text{\degree}$ phase shift in degrees.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Convert radians to degrees: $\phi = \pi/4 \times (180\text{\degree}/\pi) = 45\text{\degree}$.

questions.title: Complex Sinusoidal Function
questions.question_text: For a sinusoidal function with $A = 2, f = 1\,\text{Hz}, \phi = \pi/2$, determine the complete parameters:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The parameters match: amplitude $A = 2$, frequency $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, phase $\phi = \pi/2$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Check each parameter: $A = 2$ (amplitude), $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$ (frequency), $\phi = \pi/2$ (phase).

questions.title: Trigonometric Identity Application
questions.question_text: The function $y = 2\sin^2(x)$ can be rewritten using the identity $\sin^2(x) = (1 - \cos(2x))/2$ as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $y = 2\sin^2(x) = 2 \times (1 - \cos(2x))/2 = 1 - \cos(2x)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply identity: $y = 2\sin^2(x) = 2 \times (1 - \cos(2x))/2 = 1 - \cos(2x)$.

questions.title: Sound Wave Frequency Analysis
questions.question_text: A sound wave representing musical note $A_4$ has frequency $f = 440\,\text{Hz}$. Calculate its period $T$ in milliseconds using $T = 1/f$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $T = 1/f = 1/440\,\text{Hz} = 0.00227\,\text{s} = 2.27\,\text{ms}$ for $A_4$ pitch.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Period $T = 1/f = 1/440\,\text{Hz} = 0.00227\,\text{s} = 2.27\,\text{ms}$. Convert seconds to milliseconds.

questions.title: Frequency Domain Audio Processing
questions.question_text: Which application primarily utilizes frequency domain analysis for signal enhancement?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Audio filtering targets specific frequency bands to remove noise while preserving desired signals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency domain analysis is essential for filtering applications that manipulate specific frequency components.

questions.title: FM Radio Frequency Identification
questions.question_text: Why are FM radio stations identified by frequency (e.g., "$95.5\,\text{FM}$")?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! FM stations use frequency modulation at specific carrier frequencies: $95.5\,\text{MHz}$ in this example.
questions.feedback_incorrect: FM radio stations are identified by their carrier frequency in the VHF band ($88-108\,\text{MHz}$).

questions.title: Audio Equalizer Frequency Manipulation
questions.question_text: Audio equalizers adjust amplitude gains for different frequency bands, demonstrating practical frequency domain signal processing.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Equalizers implement frequency-selective gain control using band-pass filters and frequency domain principles.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Equalizers are classic examples of frequency domain applications, adjusting specific frequency ranges independently.

questions.title: Low-Pass Filter Frequency Response
questions.question_text: How does a low-pass filter operate in the frequency domain?
choices: Passes low frequencies, attenuates high frequencies
questions.correct_answer: Passes low frequencies, attenuates high frequencies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Low-pass filters: $H(\omega) \approx 1$ for $\omega < \omega_c$ and $H(\omega) \approx 0$ for $\omega > \omega_c$ (cutoff frequency).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Low-pass filters selectively pass frequencies below the cutoff frequency $\omega_c$ while attenuating higher frequencies.

questions.title: Cellular Communication Frequency Bands
questions.question_text: Cell phones utilize multiple frequency bands (e.g., $850\,\text{MHz}$, $1900\,\text{MHz}$, $2.4\,\text{GHz}$) for communication with base stations.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Cellular systems use frequency division multiple access (FDMA) across various bands for different services.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Modern cell phones operate across multiple frequency bands to support different protocols and coverage areas.

questions.title: Band-Pass Filter Audio Application
questions.question_text: In audio processing, what function does a band-pass filter serve?
choices: Passes only frequencies within range $[f_1, f_2]$
questions.correct_answer: Passes only frequencies within range $[f_1, f_2]$
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Band-pass filters: $H(\omega) \neq 0$ for $\omega_1 \le \omega \le \omega_2$, $H(\omega) \approx 0$ elsewhere.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Band-pass filters selectively pass frequencies within a defined bandwidth while rejecting frequencies outside this range.

questions.title: WiFi Channel Frequency Calculation
questions.question_text: WiFi operates in $2.4\,\text{GHz}$ ISM band. If Channel 1 uses $2.412\,\text{GHz}$ and channels are spaced $5\,\text{MHz}$ apart, calculate Channel 6 frequency in $\text{GHz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Channel 6 = $2.412\,\text{GHz} + (6-1) \times 0.005\,\text{GHz} = 2.412 + 0.025 = 2.437\,\text{GHz}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use frequency formula: $f_6 = f_1 + (\text{channel_offset}) \times \text{spacing} = 2.412 + 5 \times 0.005 = 2.437\,\text{GHz}$.

questions.title: Circuit Oscillation Analysis
questions.question_text: How would an engineer diagnose unwanted oscillations in an electronic circuit?
choices: Frequency spectrum analysis to identify problematic frequencies
questions.correct_answer: Frequency spectrum analysis to identify problematic frequencies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Spectrum analysis reveals oscillation frequencies, enabling targeted troubleshooting and filter design.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency domain analysis using spectrum analyzers identifies oscillation frequencies for effective circuit debugging.

questions.title: Pure Sine Wave Spectrum
questions.question_text: A pure sinusoid $x(t) = A \sin(2\pi f_0 t)$ at $f_0 = 100\,\text{Hz}$ produces what frequency spectrum?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pure sinusoids have discrete spectra: $X(f) = (A/2j)[\delta(f-f_0) - \delta(f+f_0)]$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A pure sine wave contains only one frequency component, appearing as a single spike in the frequency domain.

questions.title: Frequency Spectrum Amplitude Interpretation
questions.question_text: In a frequency spectrum plot, the height of each spectral line represents:
choices: Amplitude or energy of frequency component
questions.correct_answer: Amplitude or energy of frequency component
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Spectral magnitude $|X(f)|$ indicates the amplitude/energy content at each frequency.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency spectrum height represents the magnitude or energy content of each frequency component in the signal.

questions.title: Dual-Tone Signal Spectrum
questions.question_text: The spectrum of $x(t) = A_1\sin(2\pi\cdot 100t) + A_2\sin(2\pi\cdot 200t)$ with $A_1 = A_2$ shows:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Linear superposition: each sinusoid contributes independently to the frequency spectrum.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Superposition principle: multiple sinusoids appear as separate spectral lines at their respective frequencies.

questions.title: Silent Signal Spectrum Interpretation
questions.question_text: A frequency spectrum with no visible spikes necessarily indicates a completely silent signal (zero amplitude).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Low-amplitude signals or noise floors may not show visible spikes but still contain energy.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Signals may have low amplitude below display threshold or contain broadband noise not visible as discrete spikes.

questions.title: DC Component Spectrum Identification
questions.question_text: A large spectral component at $f = 0\,\text{Hz}$ indicates the signal contains:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $X(0)$ represents the DC component: $\int x(t)dt$, the signal's average value.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A spike at $0\,\text{Hz}$ (DC) indicates a constant offset or average value in the time-domain signal.

questions.title: Zero-Mean Sine Wave Spectrum
questions.question_text: For $x(t) = 5\sin(2\pi\cdot 10t)$ with zero DC offset, identify the number of spectral peaks in the magnitude spectrum.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Zero-mean sinusoid produces one peak at $f = 10\,\text{Hz}$ (ignoring negative frequencies in magnitude spectrum).
questions.feedback_incorrect: A pure sinusoid with no DC offset creates a single spectral line at its fundamental frequency.

questions.title: Signal Complexity Correlation
questions.question_text: Signals with many spectral components typically appear more complex in the time domain than signals with few frequency components.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! More frequency components create more complex time-domain waveforms through superposition.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier theory: complex time signals result from superposition of multiple frequency components.

questions.title: Equal-Amplitude Multi-Tone Analysis
questions.question_text: A spectrum with equal-height spikes at $100\,\text{Hz}$, $200\,\text{Hz}$, $300\,\text{Hz}$, and $400\,\text{Hz}$ indicates:
choices: Equal energy at these four frequencies
questions.correct_answer: Equal energy at these four frequencies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Equal spectral magnitudes indicate equal energy distribution across these frequency components.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Spectral line heights represent energy distribution; equal heights mean equal energy at those frequencies.
